1435632574844575752.text:
Myth #5: SNAP completely covers the costs of food for recipients

Fact: SNAP was built to supplement household food costs, not completely cover them. In fact, prior to the Thrifty Food Plan update, SNAP did not cover the cost of a low-income meal in 96% of U.S. counties. https://t.co/Ga1kooiQAA

1435632571401097219.text:
Myth #4: SNAP disincentivizes work

Fact: A majority of SNAP recipients who can work, do work. More than 80% of SNAP households work in the year before or the year after receiving SNAP. https://t.co/v8XoClNqw5

1435632568569827333.text:
Myth #3: SNAP is rife with fraud

Fact: SNAP fraud is exceedingly rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, less than .01% of 
benefits have been mistakenly issued due to recipient fraud. https://t.co/02FnPEkkPJ

1435632565860327427.text:
Myth #2: Charities can replace the help SNAP provides

Fact: While food banks provide meals for food-insecure communities, SNAP is far more wide-reaching and efficient. SNAP delivers nine times more food to people than all the food banks in the country. https://t.co/VV6rhAqPjl

1435632561942896642.text:
Myth #1: SNAP drains the economy

Fact: For every dollar utilized by a SNAP recipient, $1.79 is infused into their local economy. Additionally, SNAP lowers healthcare costs by nearly $1,400 per person. https://t.co/mIH2eluwJ1

1435632558734200844.text: On October 1st, SNAP benefits will increase by 21% permanently. I know there are many misconceptions about the program. Here are five common myths and facts about SNAP benefits you should know. https://t.co/AQAqZ2n1vi

1408477822155374596.text: Americans deserve equal opportunity to choose their elected leaders. I voted to pass the For The People Act (H.R.1), to expand access to the ballot, reduce the influence of money in politics, and implement anti-corruption measures.

1408477821064945670.text: While the House has responded to these actions by passing H.R. 1, the For The People Act, the Senate must do the same to restore these vital protections.

1408477819852800006.text: The decision has unleashed a wave of voter restriction bills aimed at suppressing the rights of our most vulnerable populations, with more than 400 bills introduced at the state level this year.

1397624691599290373.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - "To hear you say that you understand that we are 'not people who want to be on food assistance' is extremely emotional. This is not something we want permanently," shared Ms. Wilson, one of the witnesses present today.

1397623646156378117.text:
We are still in a hunger crisis, and our communities still need our help.  @RepDonBacon let’s work together to find solutions to this problem.
@HouseAgDems @HouseAgGOP

1397622100257558531.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - “As the title of this hearing indicates, we are starting to take strides in moving past the pandemic and I think this is a timely conversation we are having here today," said @repjulialetlow

1397620753181388809.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - "This is not a charity. This is our moral obligation." - @RepMcGovern "To be poor in this country is a full time job."

1397620751860183040.text: . @RepMcGovern added "I'm grateful that in the American Rescue Plan we upped it by 15% but talk to food banks and they'll tell you that people are still coming to food banks midway through the month because their benefits have run out."

1397620750400491521.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepMcGovern continued " My criticism to SNAP is that the benefit is too small. On average it is $1.40 /person/meal. My Dunkin Donuts coffee this morning cost me more than that."

1397620749071003651.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepMcGovern "SNAP is the most important anti-hunger program that we have. Charity can't do it alone, and by the way, SNAP is not charity."

1397618023419240457.text: "If they could get access to somebody else making it for them, and still have that self-pride of getting a meal, they will not have to go to junk-food." - #TheFutureofSNAP

1397618022358134785.text: #TheFutureofSNAP witness Ms. Davis continued "There are people who don't have a stove. They're not very skilled at cooking or know much about it..."

1397618021246677001.text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAlLawsonJr  asks about the impact of inadequate support from SNAP to meet the needs of families lacking hot food access, especially during natural disasters such as hurricanes.

Witness Ms. Davis shared "It is good to have access to hot meals."

1397615266582966277.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @Kilili_Sablan spoke on bringing SNAP benefits to the Northern Mariana Islands. "I had conversations with those who are home bound & some of them lost their qualification for food assistance because their income is $2 higher than the threshold.”

1397613904218492928.text: #TheFutureofSNAP "It has to be collaboratively co-designed with community partners, so that we are utilizing all of the assets and existing resources within communities most productively and we are reaching families deepest in need." - @RBoyntonJarrett

1397613903224492032.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepKatCammack asked @RBoyntonJarrett how we may be able to look at ways to promote healthy food, support our [food] producers, and meet the needs of families and individuals struggling.

1397610449676509184.text: @RepJimmyPanetta added that when he volunteered at food banks, he saw the growing lines. "What I've realized and what I believe is, we couldn't food bank our way out of the pandemic and we cannot food bank our way out of hunger."

1397610448564932610.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepJimmyPanetta "Nearly 9% of my constituents relied on SNAP, 1/4 children were food insecure, & by the end of last year, household food insecurity spiked to above 35% in certain parts of my district."

1397608388155039744.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAnnieKuster "Food insecurity is plaguing my state, and while I appreciate the role of the churches, I certainly believe that the government has an important role to this as well, to ensure equity..."

1397607045432549388.text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - "We need to work much more collaboratively to build a more resilient food system, and SNAP is a big piece of that. Also engaging parents and members of the community..." @RBoyntonJarrett 
Chronic food insecurity is traumatic & an experience you will not forget.

1397605438993190915.text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepCarbajal "I personally know how critical food assistance can be for families. When I was young, these programs actually helped reduce the financial barriers for my parents, who were struggling to get by making minimum wage, working as farm workers."

1397603372778262531.text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAdams shared that she was once a SNAP recipient and understands the experience many are encountering.

"Working hard is not enough, if you don't make enough."

1397599697628499971.text: Wilson continued to express her concern for the well-being of her children. Wilson is working diligently on recovering from job loss and decrease in work due to the pandemic. She hopes that she never has to experience this again. #TheFutureofSNAP

1397598981312679936.text: "Sometimes we [parents] set aside all of our pride to ensure our kids don't experience the effects of poverty."

1397598979924299777.text: "I am doing my very best with government assistance to get them the very best they need." Before the pandemic, she did not need government assistance.

1397598978540253186.text:
#TheFutureofSNAP SNAP recipient & witness Ms. Wilson, a mother a mother of 2, shared candidly about her children and her experience with SNAP.

"Government assistance is not a way of life," said Wilson.

1397597151539175428.text: #TheFutureofSNAP "We know that when children lack basic access to these basic necessities, even for brief periods of time, their health is jeopardized...They are more likely to be in poor health, hospitalized, & at risk for developmental delays." Dr.@RBoyntonJarrett

1397594637465006080.text: #TheFutureofSNAP witness Mr. Whitford, executive director of the Watered Gardens Ministries shared his experience those without a home. He reflects on the SNAP legislation over last two decades that impacted many around the country who were unsure of what was next.

1397592078973120521.text:

#TheFutureofSNAP

1397592075420540929.text:
Davis started a support group,"Back on Track," with other single mothers in community college who were sharing similar experiences as her. The group was a success with supporting others.

1397592073134616580.text: SNAP recipient & witness today, Odessa Davis shares "I had to put my pride to the side and get the assistance I needed." SNAP helped her with her bills due to minimum wage pay, and her son who was able to stay nourished while at school allowing him to stay focused.

1397586335578329099.text:
On this Subcommittee, we have an opportunity to ensure that these supports are strengthened for Americans in each of our districts. I am excited about this work and look forward to continuing to deliver for the American people. 
https://t.co/nXUaiduWNd

1397586334290784269.text: They are a critical support which ensures that hunger is not another obstacle in the way of Americans striving for stability.

1397586054656544768.text: That memory of stress, and the threat of hunger, is a reality that I take into this work as Chairwoman of this Subcommittee. My lived experience has shown me that SNAP, and other safety net programs, are not just hand-outs for people unwilling to work toward self-sufficiency.

1397586053381361669.text: As a young mother, I worked two jobs and attended school. But I still qualified for benefits. SNAP allowed me to put food in my children’s mouths while I worked by way to economic stability.

1397585738489794566.text: While anecdotally there may be such instances – these programs work and they are lifesavers. I know this because they saved my life.

1397585737319690243.text: That SNAP benefits discourage work; that emergency allotments and a 15% increase in benefits are just too expensive; that there is fraud within the SNAP program requiring updated quality control measures.

1397585736120119301.text: During this hearing, I am sure we may also hear some concerns regarding the SNAP program....

1397585120987594752.text: Hunger effects our friends and neighbors, the elderly, the disabled, single mothers, working parents, and people of all ages, races and beliefs.

1397585119955886091.text: Today’s testimony will show that fear of hunger is not an economic motivator, but an obstacle to success, and threat to public health. And that hunger does not discriminate. It exists in every one of our districts.

1397585118953414658.text: This testimony will illustrate what I know to be true from first-hand experience: that SNAP is a hand-up, not a hand-out, for Americans striving to achieve self-sufficiency.

1397585117808312320.text: As we will hear from our panel of witnesses today, SNAP during COVID has been crucial for those suddenly without an income, as well as parents forced to choose between a job and caring for their children in remote school.

1397584528940601358.text: –and also to use those lessons as a roadmap for closing the glaring gaps in policy which left so many Americans food insecure in the first place.

1397584527929794563.text: The title of today’s hearing is “The Future of SNAP: Moving Past the Pandemic.” The purpose of this hearing is to recount the lessons we have learned about food security and nutrition access during the COVID-19 crisis...

1358869813116997635.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC I am looking forward to more chats in the future. It was great to discuss the strides we have made in bridging the #DigitalDivide, closing the #HomeworkGap, and the work that still needs to be done to improve access to education for all. #TelecomActChat

1358867745505488896.text: @FCC The pandemic highlighted and exacerbated the issues we were already aware of with the #DigitalDivide. Many households do not have access to broadband and that leaves them behind in school, jobs, and everyday life. We need connections now more than ever. #TelecomActChat

1358867063423516679.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC So much of school today requires the internet. We risk widening the achievement gap if we do not fix this soon. We need to make sure the internet is affordable and accessible for everyone. #TelecomActChat

1358866834569723904.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC The #homeworkgap needs attention. Millions of kids across this country—in rural and urban and everywhere in between—can not do their homework or participate in class during the #COVID19 pandemic because they cannot get online. #TelecomActChat

1358866595825799176.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC This is an issue that is close to my heart. It is something that I have seen firsthand - students struggling through lack of internet access in Waterbury, Connecticut. #TelecomActChat

1358865572021366786.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC But now, we need to expand #ERate beyond schools and into the homes of students as so many kids are learning remotely during this pandemic. #TelecomActChat

1358865419793235971.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC #ERate and being able to use the internet to expand my students’ horizons was critical. #TelecomActChat

1358864912571891714.text: @FCC This bill created a Universal Service Fund to support access by those in rural areas, as well as low-income Americans. It demonstrated that broadband connectivity must reach all Americans, regardless of who they are or where they live. #TelecomActChat

1358863553252495366.text: @FCC The Telecom Act started us down the path of ever-expanding network connectivity. It recognized the importance of digital access and equity – something we are still working on today. And it codified the idea that the internet should be affordable for all.  #TelecomActChat

1358861939305295879.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC As a career educator, I am especially interested in how this law brought the internet into schools and libraries. How it has changed how teachers teach and students learn. #TelecomActChat

1358861728008839175.text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC Thanks @FCC & Acting Chairwoman @JRosenworcelFCC for chatting today. It is always a privilege to take a break from my day job in Congress and return to what I love best - teaching. #TelecomActChat

1270660081869377536.text: The legislation leverages access to existing federal funding by conditioning it upon increased training, banning practices like chokeholds and no-knock warrants, limiting use of force, and requiring public reporting when force is used.

1270660080837570561.text: The Justice in Policing Act of 2020 does not in any way defund the police. It holds police accountable by giving American citizens recourse if they believe there has been a violation.

1270660079977746432.text: Simultaneously, I support addressing the underlying, structural inequalities which expose communities to police violence.

1270660077742104577.text:
